title: GBBO's Nadiya Hussain reveals suicide attempt after sexually assault
text:
Nadiya has also released a children’s cook book (Picture: BBC/Wall to Wall Media/Adam Lawrence)

Great British Bake Off winner Nadiya Hussain has revealed her trauma of being sexually assaulted by a relative during her childhood.

The baker had previously talked about the panic attacks she suffered ‘every few days’ while filming for the 2015 series.

Speaking to the Mail on Sunday for the release of her memoir Finding My Voice, she said: ‘No doubt that would have played a role in my PTSD, my panic disorder.

‘It must have done, because it’s a memory that has stayed with me forever.’

The bullying she endured at school added to the pile and she was once told she had her head stuck down a toilet for being ‘too dark’.

She further admitted that the first time she head the term suicide, she considered it a ‘bus ticket’ away from misery.

‘It was like, “What? I can buy this ticket and I can just go and I’d never get bullied again?”,’ she said.

She also talked about the Bangladesh attacks (Picture: Jeff Spicer/PA Wire)

The star attempted to overdose on tablets but was interrupted by the news that her mother was pregnant with her brother.

She then decided to live on for her brother.

Nadiya had kept what happened to her to herself, admitting she only recently told her sister.

‘I’ve only told my sisters recently and, growing up, I had a close friend at school who I told. It turned out a very similar thing had happened to her.

‘It’s important to talk about it because it probably happens much more than we care to talk about.

‘If that happened to my children, I don’t even want to say what I would do. I have no words.’

The chef won with her cake that she named My Big Fat British Wedding cake which was a raspberry-flavoured mille-feuille.

Finding My Voice is out 17 October 2019.
